body_text.text: The vertebrate CNS is composed of a diverse range of morphologically and functionally distinct types of cells, and the correct functioning of the nervous system is critically dependent on the production of a sufficient and balanced number of each cell type.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This cellular diversity arises from multipotent progenitor cells by complex developmental mechanisms, including cell proliferation, fate determination, differentiation, and survival.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Identification of the molecules and mechanisms that generate the proper number of neuronal cell types is one of the major goals of developmental biology.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The retina has served as an excellent model system for studying the mechanisms of cell production in the vertebrate CNS.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: During development, progenitor cells in the presumptive neural retina give rise to six major classes of neurons and one glial cell class in an evolutionally conserved order, which follows a histogenetic sequence in the retina (Price et al., 1987;Holt et al., 1988;Wetts and Fraser, 1988).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The first cells that emerge from the retinal progenitor cells are retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), which are the sole output neurons in the retina and locate in the innermost layer (the ganglion cell layer [GCL]) of the mature retina (Prada et al., 1991).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Whereas cell-intrinsic mechanisms play crucial roles in retinal cell diversification (Cayouette et al., 2006), several extrinsic signals derived from various sources in the eye influence RGC development (Isenmann et al., 2003;Agathocleous and Harris, 2009), including fibroblast growth factors (FGFs;McCabe et al., 1999,
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: To explore potential functions of Nel in retinal development, we first examined its spatial and temporal expression patterns in the developing chick eye by RNA in situ hybridization.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: In chicks, invagination of the primary optic vesicle starts at Hamburger Hamilton stage (HH) 14 (embryonic day [E] 2.5), and the double-layered optic cup is formed at HH15 (E2.5).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: At those stages, Nel RNA expression was detected in the outer layer of the optic cup, the presumptive retinal pigment epithelium (RPE; Figure 1A).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: At HH20 (E3.5), Nel expression in the RPE increased, and, in addition, significant expression of Nel RNA was detected in cells that occupy the inner surface of the central retina ( Figure 1B), where newly differentiated RGCs reside.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Nel RNA expression in RGCs increased between E4 and E6 ( Figure 1C).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Expression of Nel persisted and continued to be restricted to the RPE and RGCs at least until E18 (Figure 1, C′, D, and D′).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: The observed strong expression of Nel in 2006; Martinez-Morales et al., 2005), Sonic hedgehog (Shh; Zhang and Yang, 2001a;Masai et al., 2005), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF; Hashimoto et al., 2006), and Delta-Notch signaling (Austin et al., 1995).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Considering the complexity of cellular and molecular interactions that mediate retinal development, however, it seems likely that additional extracellular signals are involved in regulation of RGC development.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Nel (neural epidermal growth factor [EGF]-like) is an extracellular glycoprotein that was initially identified in chickens (Matsuhashi et al., 1995(Matsuhashi et al., , 1996.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: In mammals, two related genes were subsequently identified and termed Nel-like 1 (Nell1) and 2 (Watanabe et al., 1996;Kuroda et al., 1999).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Based on sequence similarities, Nell2 appeared to be the mammalian orthologue of chicken Nel.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: In this article, we refer to both Nel and Nell2 as Nel.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: The Nel/Nell proteins have significant structural similarities with thrombospondin-1, which plays important roles in a wide range of physiological and pathological conditions, such as tumor growth and metastasis, angiogenesis, wound healing, inflammation, and synaptogenesis (Adams and Lawler, 2011).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: The Nel protein contains an N-terminal thrombospondin-1 domain, five chordin-like/von Willebrand factor C domains, and six EGF-like domains (Matsuhashi et al., 1995(Matsuhashi et al., , 1996.
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Retinal sections prepared from different stages of chick embryos were hybridized with an RNA probe for Nel (violet).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye
Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: RNA expression of Nel is initially restricted to the presumptive RPE (pe; A) but is also detected in RGCs (gc) at later stages (B-D).
body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: Nel RNA expression in the RPE and RGCs persists until at least E18 (D).

body_text.text: In C and D, higher-magnification views of the RPE (areas indicated by small rectangles) are shown in insets (C′ and D′, respectively).

body_text.section: Nel is expressed in retinal pigment epithelium and RGCs in the developing chick eye

body_text.text: The expression patterns of Nel in early retinal development raised the possibility that Nel may be involved in retinal neurogenesis, particularly in development of RGCs.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: To test this possibility directly in vivo, we constructed a replication-competent retroviral vector that drives bicistronic expression of Nel and an enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) marker (RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: As a negative control, we used the RCAS-IRES-EGFP vector, which expresses only EGFP.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The expression vectors were transfected into the optic vesicle at HH9-11 (E1.5) by in ovo electroporation, and expression of the transgenes was assessed at later stages by fluorescence of EGFP and immunohistochemistry using anti-Nel antibody (Jiang et al., 2009; Figure 2, A-F).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: To examine effects of Nel overexpression on RGC development, we incubated embryos transfected with the RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP vector until E8, when production of RGCs is mostly complete (Prada et al., 1991).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Retinal sections were then prepared and stained for Brn3a, a specific marker for RGCs in the retina (Xiang et al., 1995).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Retinal neurogenesis occurs in a central-to-peripheral gradient (Snow and Robson, 1995;McCabe et al., 1999) and also shows slight temporal-to-nasal and dorsal-to-ventral gradients (Prada et al., 1991).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We therefore compared the numbers of Brn3a-positive cells between equivalent areas (e.g., central-temporal area) of transfected and untransfected (contralateral) retinas.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We found that the number of Brn3a-positive cells increased by approximately 40% in regions transfected with RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP ( Figure  2, G-L).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Transfection of the control vector that expresses only EGFP did not affect the production of Brn3a-positive cells in the retina ( Figure 2L).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: During vertebrate retinal development, significant numbers of amacrine cells, which are mainly located in the superficial part of the inner nuclear layer (INL), migrate to the GCL.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: In chicks, those "displaced" amacrine cells are produced between E5.5 and E6.5 and comprise 20-35% of the total number of cells in the GCL (Galvez et al., 1977;Ehrlich and Morgan, 1980;Layer and Vollmer, 1982).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Therefore next we examined whether Nel overexpression affects the number of displaced amacrine cells by using the amacrine cell marker syntaxin.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We found that in the retinal regions where Nel is overexpressed, the number of displaced amacrine cells in the GCL significantly decreases.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The total cell numbers in the GCL showed a slight increase after Nel overexpression, although this difference was not statistically significant ( Figure 2L).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: These results indicate that Nel overexpression promotes the genesis of RGCs and decreases the number of displaced amacrine cells in the GCL.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: RGCs is consistent with previous reports (Nelson et al., 2002;Wang et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Because Nel is a secreted protein, it could in principle diffuse distances to be distributed in neighboring layers and tissues.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We therefore examined the Nel protein distribution in the developing retina by immunohistochemistry using anti-Nel antibody (Jiang et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The distribution of the Nel protein showed a very similar pattern to that of Nel RNA expression ( Figure 1, E-G), indicating that most of the secreted Nel protein remains in the layers of its origin.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: This result is consistent with our previous observation that Nel RNA and protein show similar layer-specific distributions in the developing chick optic tectum (Jiang et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: This limited diffusion of the Nel protein may be due to its heparin-binding activity (Kuroda et al., 1999;Nakamura et al., 2012), and the Nel protein may be trapped by heparin sulfate proteoglycans in situ soon after secretion from Nel-expressing cells.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo
Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Higher-magnification views of the RPE (areas indicated by small rectangles in A and D, respectively).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: In Nel/EGFP transfection domains, ectopic expression of Nel in progenitor cells (pc) of the neural retina is detected.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: In addition, staining for the Nel protein in RGCs (gc) and RPE (pe) is stronger compared to that in control areas.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: (G-L)

body_text.text: Effects of Nel overexpression on RGC production.

body_text.text: Retinal sections were prepared at E8 from embryos transfected with RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP, and the production of RGCs was evaluated by immunohistochemistry for Brn3a (red).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The transgene was introduced into half of the retina (overexpression [OE] side), which is marked by the EGFP reporter (green).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: (I) Merged image of G and H. (J, K) Higher-magnification views of Nel-overexpressing and corresponding untransfected areas in G (indicated by small rectangles), respectively.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The number of Brn3a-positive cells significantly increased in Nel ectopic domains.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: on, optic nerve head.

body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: (L) Quantification of cell numbers in the GCL.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: The numbers of Brn3a-positive RGCs, syntaxin-positive displaced amacrine cells, and total cells in the GCL (4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) in areas transfected with Nel and EGFP (Nel/EGFP) or EGFP only (EGFP) were compared with those in equivalent areas of the contralateral (untransfected) eye (Control) and indicated as mean ± SEM.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo
Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: n = 6 embryos.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: ANOVA test.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Tol2 transposable element (Koga et al., 1996).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We made a Tol2 transposon construct (pT2K-CAGGS-Nel miRNA482/2461-emerald GFP [EmGFP]) that expresses Nel-specific miRNA and an EmGFP marker under the CAGGS promoter.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: As a negative control, we used a transposon vector carrying nonspecific miRNA sequences with the EmGFP marker gene (pT2K-CAGGS-Control miRNA-EmGFP).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: When introduced into cells with a transposase activity, the expression cassette would be excised from the plasmid and integrated into the host genome, allowing stable expression of the miRNA and the EmGFP marker ( Figure 3A).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: We electroporated the transposon vector of Nel miRNA with the transposase expression vector pCAGGS-T2TP into the optic vesicle at HH9-11 (E1.5).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Electroporation efficiency was monitored by expression of EmGFP, and effects of RNA interference (RNAi) on Nel expression was evaluated by immunohistochemistry using anti-Nel antibody.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: At E4.5, endogenous expression of Nel was found to be significantly reduced in EmGFPexpressing cells in the RPE (Figure 3, B-D).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: At E8, reduction of Nel expression was also obvious in RGCs (Figure 3, E-I).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Then we examined whether RNAi knockdown of Nel affects the numbers of RGCs and displaced amacrine cells.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Whereas transfection of the control vector did not cause any changes in the RGC or displaced amacrine cell numbers, introduction of the Nel miRNA construct with the transposase expression vector resulted in an approximately 40% reduction in the number of Brn3a-positive cells and to a lesser extent, an increase in the number of displaced amacrine cells ( Figure 4).
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Taken together, these results indicate that Nel regulates the number of RGCs positively and that of displaced amacrine cells negatively and is essential for the generation of the proper numbers of retinal neurons during development.
body_text.section: Nel overexpression increases RGC number in vivo

body_text.text: Next we tested whether Nel overexpression or knockdown affects the production of other types of retinal cells.
body_text.section: Effects of Nel on other types of retinal cells

body_text.text: To this end, we examined the numbers of different types of retinal cells at E18 by using AP2α as a bipolar cell marker, Pax6 as a horizontal cell marker, rhodopsin as a marker for rods, visinin as a marker for cones, and vimentin as a Müller glia marker.
body_text.section: Effects of Nel on other types of retinal cells

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 5, neither overexpression nor RNAi knockdown caused significant changes in the numbers of those retinal cells.
body_text.section: Effects of Nel on other types of retinal cells

body_text.text: In addition, the amacrine cell numbers in the INL were not significantly altered by the modulations of Nel expression levels.
body_text.section: Effects of Nel on other types of retinal cells

body_text.text: These results indicate that the effects of Nel expression are confined to the GCL of the retina.
body_text.section: Effects of Nel on other types of retinal cells

body_text.text: Next we examined whether Nel is essential for the production of the proper number of RGCs in vivo.
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: To test this, we designed artificial microRNAs (miRNAs) to target Nel expression and introduced them into the developing eye by in ovo electroporation.
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: Because RGC production continues over at least 5-6 d, it was necessary that the production of the artificial miRNA be maintained throughout the period of RGC generation without significant reduction in expression.
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: To achieve stable expression of transgenes, we used a transposon-mediated gene transfer system (Sato et al., 2007) that uses the antibody.
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: Neither overexpression nor RNAi knockdown of Nel caused any significant change in the number of PH3-positive cells ( Figure 6, E-J).
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: These results suggest that Nel does not serve as a mitogen during early retinal development.
body_text.section: Decrease of RGC number by RNA interference knockdown of Nel

body_text.text: Next we examined the effects of Nel on RGC differentiation.
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: During development, RGC differentiation occurs in a central-toperipheral gradient, such that RGCs are initially produced in the central retina and then the wave of differentiation proceeds from the central to peripheral retina, much like an expanding circle (Snow and Robson, 1995;McCabe et al., 1999).
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: In addition, it was reported that neurogenesis in the chick retina shows slight temporal-to-nasal and dorsalto-ventral gradients (Prada et al., 1991).
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: To test whether Nel affects the progression of the RGC differentiation wave, we overexpressed Nel in half (nasal or temporal) of the retina at HH9-11 (E1.5), and examined the progression of RGC differentiation by immunohistochemistry for the RGC marker Islet-1 (Austin et al., 1995) at E4.5, when RGCs are still actively produced.
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: Equal numbers of nasally and temporally transfected retinas were examined.
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: We found that the overexpressing side of the retina contained significantly larger numbers of Islet-1-positive cells than the control side ( Figure 7, A, B, and E).
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: Furthermore, compared to the control side, the peripheral edge or front of RGC differentiation reached farther from the central toward peripheral retina ( Figure 7, A, B, and F), indicating that Nel overexpression accelerates the movement of the RGC differentiation wave.
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: Conversely, when expression of Nel was knocked down by RNAi in half of the retina, the knockdown side of the retina not only contained fewer Islet-1-positive cells, but also showed slower progression of the RGC differentiation wave (Figure 7, C-F).
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: These results indicate that Nel enhances the rate of RGC differentiation and its progression from the central to peripheral retina.
body_text.section: Nel accelerates the progression of RGC differentiation wave

body_text.text: In retinal development, the period of RGC production partly overlaps with the earlier peak phase of developmental cell death (Frade et al., 1997).
body_text.section: Nel protects retinal cells from developmental cell death

body_text.text: Therefore next we examined whether manipulations of Nel expression levels affect programmed cell death during retinal development.
body_text.section: Nel protects retinal cells from developmental cell death

body_text.text: Consistent with previous reports (Zhang and Yang, 2001a,b), only a few apoptotic cells were detected by terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling (TUNEL) assay in central regions of the normal E6 retina.
body_text.section: Nel protects retinal cells from developmental cell death

body_text.text: Overexpression of Nel resulted in a decrease in the number of TUNEL-positive cells in transfected areas (Figure 8, A, B, and E).
body_text.section: Nel protects retinal cells from developmental cell death

body_text.text: Conversely, when Nel expression was knocked down by RNAi, a marked increase in the number of TUNEL-positive cells was
body_text.section: Nel protects retinal cells from developmental cell death

body_text.text: The potential mechanisms by which Nel positively regulates RGC production include stimulation of retinal progenitor proliferation, promotion of RGC differentiation, and inhibition of apoptosis.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: First, we tested whether Nel can enhance proliferation of progenitor cells in the developing retina.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: We electroporated RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP into the optic vesicle at HH9-11 (E1.5) and counted the number of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU)-positive cells after 3 h of in vivo labeling at E6.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: No significant difference in the number of BrdU-positive cells was observed between Nel-overexpressing and control areas ( Figure  6, A, B, and I).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: In addition, RNAi knockdown of Nel expression did not affect the number of BrdU-positive cells ( Figure 6, C, D, and J).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: In a separate set of experiments, retinal sections were examined by immunohistochemistry using anti-phosphohistone H3 (PH3)  Xenopus embryos, overexpression of FGF2 in retinal progenitor cells results in a 35% increase of RGCs without affecting retinal cell proliferation (Patel and McFarlane, 2000).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Whereas both Nel and FGF1 accelerate the progression of RGC differentiation wave, the central-to-peripheral gradient of RGC differentiation is preserved in the presence of excess Nel or FGF1.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Given that the cells at the wave front are more mature than those in the peripheral retina, these results may suggest that Nel and FGF1 act to stimulate further differentiation of nascent RGCs in final stages of RGC development (Jiang et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Programmed cell death plays crucial roles in regulation of cell numbers during neural development, and a significant portion of newly generated RGCs undergo programmed cell death during development.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: The present study shows that whereas Nel overexpression decreases number of apoptotic cells in the developing retina, RNAi knockdown of Nel dramatically increases it.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: These results suggest that in addition to acceleration of RGC differentiation, suppression of developmental cell death contributes to promotion of RGC production by Nel.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Importance of developmental cell death in regulation of RGC numbers has also been shown by studies on brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Application of BDNF to chick embryos in ovo significantly inhibits the earlier peak phase of developmental cell death in the retina and results in a 60-90% increase in RGC number (Frade et al., 1997).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Nel was shown to promote survival of cortical and hippocampal neurons in primary culture (Aihara et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: More recently, it was reported that overexpression of Nel in the retina promotes RGC survival in vivo after optic nerve transection (Munemasa et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: These results indicate that Nel can act as a survival factor for multiple types of neurons.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: We found that the number of displaced amacrine cells in the GCL is negatively affected by Nel expression.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Given that amacrine cells are among the early-born neurons in the retina and are generated at approximately the same time as RGCs (Cepko et al., 1996), Nel may act to cause a cell fate shift from amacrine cells to RGCs, although the change in amacrine cell number is restricted in the GCL, and no significant effects were observed on amacrine cell number in the INL by Nel overexpression or RNAi knockdown.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: Alternatively, the displacement of amacrine cells in the GCL may be negatively controlled by the number of RGCs in the layer, and thus the observed effects on the number of displaced amacrine cells may represent secondary effects due to the change of RGC number caused by modulation of Nel expression.
body_text.section: Nel does not significantly affect proliferation of retinal progenitor cells

body_text.text: During retinal development, Nel is produced by two different sources in the eye (Figure 9).
body_text.section: Nel in molecular interaction network during retinal development

body_text.text: First, at early stages of retinal development before the first RGCs emerge in the GCL, the presumptive RPE acts as the sole source of Nel in the developing eye.
body_text.section: Nel in molecular interaction network during retinal development

body_text.text: Throughout eye development, the neural retina and the RPE are kept in close apposition, and development of the two tissues occurs in observed (Figure 8, C-E).
body_text.section: Nel in molecular interaction network during retinal development

body_text.text: Transfection of control vectors did not change the number of TUNEL-positive cells (Supplemental Figure  S1).
body_text.section: Nel in molecular interaction network during retinal development

body_text.text: These results indicate that Nel acts to protect RGCs from programmed cell death during retinal development.
body_text.section: Nel in molecular interaction network during retinal development

body_text.text: Several lines of evidence obtained in this study indicate that Nel positively regulates the production of RGCs during development.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: First, Nel is strongly expressed in RGCs (Nelson et al., 2002;Wang et al., 2007) and the RPE in the developing eye.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Second, gain-offunction studies show that retroviral overexpression of Nel in the developing retina increases RGC number.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Third, loss-of-function experiments using RNAi knockdown demonstrate that reduction of Nel expression levels results in decreased number of RGCs.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: We also showed that alterations of Nel expression levels do not exert obvious effects on cell proliferation but significantly affect the rate of RGC differentiation and developmental cell death, suggesting that Nel enhances the production of RGCs by promoting their differentiation and survival.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: During retinal development, RGC differentiation initially occurs in the central retina, and the wave of differentiation proceeds toward the periphery of retina.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Our results show that overexpression of Nel accelerates the progression of the RGC differentiation wave, whereas RNAi knockdown of Nel expression retards the movement of the wave front.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: This effect of Nel appears similar to that previously reported for FGF signaling.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: During the initial stage of chick retinogenesis, FGF1 is expressed at high levels in the peripheral part of the developing retina (de Iongh and McAvoy, 1992).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: In a retinal explant culture system, FGF1 promotes the progression of RGC differentiation wave, and inhibition of the FGF receptor signaling inhibits the movement of the wave front (McCabe et al., 1999).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: In from the RPE, including VEGF, FGF, and pigment epithelium-derived factor (PEDF; Strauss, 2005).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: In Xenopus, PEDF supports normal development of photoreceptor neurons and Müller cells after removal of the RPE, demonstrating that RPE-derived PEDF plays important roles in the final stages of retinal development (Jablonski et al., 2000(Jablonski et al., , 2001.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Although the Nel protein appears to localize mostly in the presumptive RPE at this stage, our results raise the possibility that RPE-derived Nel functions as a part of the molecular network between the RPE and neural retina and acts to increase, directly or indirectly, RGC production in early stages of retinal neurogenesis.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Second, strong Nel expression was detected in RGCs that had migrated into the GCL.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Previous studies showed that differentiated RGCs secrete several factors that affect RGC production.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: For example, Shh is produced by newly differentiated RGCs and required for the propagation of the neurogenic wave toward the peripheral retina (Masai et al., 2005).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Shh also suppresses the generation of additional RGCs behind the neurogenic wave front (Zhang and Yang, 2001a).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: In addition, VEGF produced by differentiated RGCs increases proliferation of retinal progenitors and decreases production of RGCs (Hashimoto et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: The present study suggests that Nel is a novel RGC-derived factor that positively regulates RGC production.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: The relative contributions and respective functions of RPE-and RGC-derived Nel in RGC production remain elusive.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: In addition, it is not clear whether RPE-derived Nel affects expression of RGC-derived Nel, or expressions of RPE-and RGC-derived Nel are independently regulated.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: We plan to address those issues in future studies by creating and analyzing conditional (RPE-and RGC-specific) knockout mice of Nel.
body_text.section: Functions of Nel in RGC development

body_text.text: Although chick embryos have long been used as a favorite model organism in the field of developmental biology, robust and efficient loss-of-function approaches had not been available for the chick until recently.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: In the past decade, RNAi has been successfully used in chick embryos by electroporating small interfering RNAs (siRNAs; Hu et al., 2002) or expression vectors for short hairpin RNA (Katahira and Nakamura, 2003) in ovo.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: More recently, an RCAS retrovirus-based siRNA delivery system was shown to efficiently knock down gene expression in chick embryos (Harpavat and Cepko, 2006).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: In loss-of-function analysis of this study, we introduced artificial miRNA transgenes into the developing chick retina by using a concert (Strauss, 2005).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Ablation of the RPE severely disrupts development of the neural retina (Stiemke et al., 1994;Raymond and Jackson, 1995).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Interestingly, compared to pigmented wild-type mice, more RGCs are produced during the initial period of retinal neurogenesis in albino mice, which lack pigmentation in the RPE.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of pigment production increases the number of RGCs in eyecups isolated from pigmented mice (Rachel et al., 2002).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: A variety of growth factors are secreted FIGURE 7: Enhancement of the progression of RGC differentiation wave by Nel.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: (A-D)
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Nel was either overexpressed (A, B) or knocked down (C, D) in half (left side) of the developing retina by in ovo electroporation at HH9-11 (E1.5).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Retinal sections were prepared at E4.5, and RGCs were detected by immunohistochemistry using anti-Islet-1 antibody (red).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: The areas of transgene expression are marked by expression of a GFP reporter (transfection side, green).
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Compared to the control side, Nel overexpression increased the number of RGCs and accelerated the progression of RGC differentiation wave.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Conversely, RNAi knockdown of Nel decreased the RGC number and slowed down the rate of their differentiation.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: The white lines indicate the midline of the retina, and the arrows show the peripheral edge of RGC differentiation wave.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: le, lens.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: (E) Quantification of RGC numbers.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: The number of Islet-1-positive cells is shown as percentage control in mean ± SEM.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: (F) Quantification of progression of the RGC differentiation wave.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: The angles subtended by the arcs of RGC cells were measured on the transfection (θt) and control sides (θc), as indicated.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Effects on wave progression were quantified as θt/θc × 100 and plotted as mean ± SEM.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Equal numbers of nasally and temporally transfected retinas were examined.

Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: n = 6 embryos each for temporal and nasal transfection.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: Paired Student's t test.
body_text.section: Gene silencing in chick embryos by transposon-mediated integration of artificial miRNA transgenes

body_text.text: In the chick visual system, Nel is expressed not only in RGCs (projecting neurons), but also in the optic tectum (the main target of RGC axons in nonmammalian vertebrates).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Nel expression in the chick tectum is detected as early as E5.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Expression levels of Nel significantly increase between E8 and E12, and the high expression is maintained at least until E18.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: First RGC axons reach the tectum by E6, and RGC axons project to the specific layers ("retinorecipient laminae") in the superficial part of the tectum between E12 and E18.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: During this period, Nel expression in the tectum is confined to deeper layers of the tectum, which RGC axons do not normally innervate ("nonretinorecipient laminae").
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Because Nel inhibits outgrowth of RGC axons and induces growth cone collapse and axon retraction in vitro, these results suggest that Nel may act as an inhibitory axon guidance cue that prevents RGC axons from invading inappropriate layers in the deeper part of the tectum and thus contribute to the establishment of the layer specificity in the visual projection (Jiang et al., 2009;Nakamura et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: In addition, in view of the functions of Nel in RGC production revealed in this study, it seems plausible that Nel could also have roles in differentiation and survival of tectal neurons in nonretinorecipient laminae.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: It is intriguing that Nel exerts both positive (promotion of differentiation and survival) and negative (inhibitory effects on axons) effects on RGCs.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Several other axon guidance molecules were also reported to exert both positive and negative effects on neurons.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Such examples include ephrins, Wnt (Flanagan, 2006), and netrins (Moore et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Because the Nel protein consists of different domains, it seems likely that different domains interact with distinct receptors and exert different functions, as is the case for thrombospondin-1 (Adams and Lawler, 2011).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Interestingly, Nel exerts neuroprotective effects on cultured neurons at concentrations lower than those required for inhibitory effects on RGC axons (Aihara et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: This may suggest that Nel exerts inhibitory axon guidance functions and neuroprotective effects through distinct receptors that have different affinities for the ligand.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Alternatively, the same receptor(s) may mediate both positive and negative signals in response to different concentrations of the ligand, as shown for Eph receptor-ephrin interactions (Hansen et al., 2004;Matsuoka et al., 2005).
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Further studies, including identification of its receptors, would be required to fully understand the molecular mechanisms of Nel functions.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Nonetheless, it has become increasingly apparent that Nel is a multifunctional molecule that plays crucial roles in development of the vertebrate nervous system and its functions.
body_text.section: Diverse functions of Nel in visual system development

body_text.text: Fertilized White Leghorn chicken eggs were purchased from Henry Stewart (Louth, United Kingdom) and incubated at 38°C until use.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: transposon-mediated gene transfer system (Sato et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: This method offers several distinct advantages.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: First, it supports stable expression of the transgene and thus persistent production of miRNA.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Electroporation of conventional expression vectors permits only transient expression of the transgene, usually lasting only for several days in embryonic cells, because of the inability of the electroporated plasmid to be integrated into chromosomes.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: In contrast, the present method involves chromosomal integration of the expression cassette by activity of coelectroporated transposase and therefore can achieve stable expression of the transgenes.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Second, the cells that express the transgene can be easily traced because each of the transfected cells is clearly marked by the EmGFP marker.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Third, because expression of miRNA and EmGFP is driven by the same CAGGS promoter, the risk of promoter interference is avoided, which is one of the common problems with retroviral vectors containing an additional promoter to attain dual gene expression (e.g., Yee et al., 1987)).
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Finally, the areas of transfection can be controlled by properly choosing the type and positions of electrodes.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Because this method does not use replication-competent retroviral vectors, there is no transmission of the transgene to neighboring cells after the electroporation.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Within the transfected retinas, areas that do not express the transgene serve as a good internal control.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: Therefore this system provides a stable and efficient loss-of-function option and can contribute to the analysis of gene functions during chick development.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: potent target sequences were selected (corresponding to nucleotide numbers 482-502 and 2461-2481, respectively) and tandemly cloned into the pcDNA6.2-GW/EmGFP-miRNA vector (pcDNA6.2-GW-Nel miRNA482/2461-EmGFP) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: To construct the pT2K-CAGGS-Nel miRNA482/2461-EmGFP vector, cDNA sequences encoding the two pre-miRNA and EmGFP of the pcDNA6.2-GW/Nel miRNA 482/2461-EmGFP vector were amplified by PCR with an artificial EcoRI site on both ends (5′-GGGAATTCTCTGGCTAACTAGA-GAAC-3′ and 5′-CCG AATTCCCTCTAGATCAACCACT-3′) and cloned into the pT2K-CAGGS vector.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: The control pT2K-CAGGS-Control miRNA-EmGFP vector was constructed by cloning the corresponding region of the pcDNA6.2-GW/EmGFP-miRNA negative control plasmid (Invitrogen) into the pT2K-CAGGS vector using the same set of PCR primers and restriction enzyme sites as mentioned.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: The pT2K-CAGGS and pCAGGS-T2TP vectors were kindly provided by Yoshiko Takahashi (Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan) and Koichi Kawakami (National Institute of Genetics, Mishima, Japan), respectively.
body_text.section: Chick embryos

body_text.text: In ovo electroporation was performed as described previously (Harada et al., 2008).
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: Briefly, a small amount of plasmid DNA solution (5 μg/μl each) mixed with fast green (dye tracer) was injected into the lumen of the optic vesicle of HH9-11 (E1.5) chick embryos in windowed eggs.
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: Parallel platinum-coated electrodes spaced at 3 mm were placed perpendicular to the long axis of the embryo, one electrode being on the anterior (nasal) side and the other electrode on the posterior (temporal) side of the optic vesicle.
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: Five square pulses (25 V, 50 ms/s) were applied by a CUY21 electroporator (Nepa Gene, Ichikawa, Japan).
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: The levels of ectopic expression varied in different embryos.
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: Only the embryos that showed significant levels of expression were used for analysis.
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: Equal numbers of nasally and temporally transfected retinas were analyzed.
body_text.section: In ovo electroporation

body_text.text: For immunohistochemistry, embryonic retinas were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde, cryoprotected with 30% sucrose in phosphatebuffered saline (PBS), embedded in OCT compound, frozen, and sectioned at 12-30 μm.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: Immunohistochemistry for Nel protein was performed as described previously (Jiang et al., 2009), except that Alexa Fluor 594-conjugated anti-rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG; 1:1000; Invitrogen) was used as secondary antibody.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: For immunostaining of Brn3a, Islet-1, PH3, Pax6, and AP2α, sections were processed for antigen retrieval in a citrate buffer solution (10 mM trisodium citrate, 0.05% Tween-20) at 95°C for 3 min, blocked in a blocking solution (10% donkey serum, 0.3% Triton X-100 in PBS) for 1 h at room temperature, and treated with primary and secondary antibodies in an antibody dilution solution (0.3% Triton X-100, 1% bovine serum albumin in PBS).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: The following antibodies were used: anti-Brn3a (1:100, clone 5A3.2; Millipore, Billerica, MA), anti-Islet-1 (1:50, clone 39.4D5; Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank [DSHB], University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA), anti-PH3 (1:100; Millipore), anti-syntaxin (1:2000; Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO), anti-Pax6 (1:200; DSHB), anti-PKCα (1:2000; Sigma-Aldrich), anti-vimentin (1:2000; DSHB), anti-rhodopsin (1:200; Sigma-Aldrich), anti-visinin (1:100; DSHB); anti-AP2-α (1:200; DSHB), Alexa Fluor 594-conjugated anti-mouse IgG (1:1,000; Invitrogen), and Alexa Fluor 488-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG (1:400; Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: The TUNEL assay was performed by using the In Situ Cell Death Detection Kit, TMR red (Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: For quantification, the number of
body_text.section: Immunohistochemistry and TUNEL assay

body_text.text: In situ RNA hybridization was performed using digoxigenin-labeled probes for Nel as previously described (Jiang et al., 2009), using 12-to 30-μm frozen sections of the embryonic retina.
body_text.section: In situ RNA hybridization

body_text.text: For construction of the RCAS-IRES-EGFP plasmid, cDNA sequences containing IRES-EGFP (nucleotide numbers 666-1973) of the pIRES2-EGFP vector (Clontech, Mountain View, CA) were amplified by PCR.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: Both the 5′ and 3′ PCR primers contain an artificial ClaI site, and the 3′ ClaI site was protected by a 5′ guanine, thus preventing ClaI cleavage when methylated, as previously described (McLaughlin et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: The PCR product was cloned into the ClaI site of the replication-competent avian retroviral vector RCAS (Fekete and Cepko, 1993).
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: The RCAS-Nel-IRES-EGFP vector was constructed by inserting the protein-coding region of Nel cDNA (GenBank accession number NM_001030740.1, nucleotide numbers 118-2565) into the RCAS-IRES-EGFP vector upstream of the IRES at the functional ClaI site.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: For RNAi knockdown, we designed pairs of single-stranded DNA oligonucleotides (one encoding target pre-miRNA and the other corresponding its complement) for 10 potential target sequences by using RNAi Designer (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA;https://rnaidesigner.invitrogen.com/rnaiexpress/).
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: After annealing, the double-stranded oligonucleotides were individually cloned into the pcDNA6.2-GW/EmGFP-miRNA vector (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: Knockdown effects of each construct were evaluated by cotransfection with a Nel-AP expression vector into HEK293T cells, followed by measurement of AP activity in the culture media.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: The two mostpositive cells in transfected retinal regions was scored in a highpower optic field and compared with that in equivalent regions of the contralateral (untransfected) retinas or corresponding control areas.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: At least three fields were examined for each retina, and at least six retinas were analyzed for each type of treatment.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: Equal numbers of nasally and temporally transfected retinas were analyzed.
body_text.section: Plasmid constructs

body_text.text: Statistical significance of the data was determined using analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Student's t test.
body_text.section: Statistical analyses

body_text.text: We thank John Flanagan and Lynda Erskine for discussions and critical reading of the manuscript; Lynda Erskine, Neil Vargesson, Bing Lang, and Freyja Bruce for help and advice on immunostaining and the TUNEL assay; and Yvonne Turnbull for technical assistance in the purchase and maintenance of chicken eggs.
